commentBody:
If anybody doesn't like this puzzle, 
or has trouble solving it, 
70 Across!

Sam: [Subway] in the 10A clue
gave away the 23A themer!

I'll be sharing 114A
with my super.


P.S.: Glad Joel replaced
Sam's working title.
Yes, this is an appropriate Sam E.  puzzle. Clevet word play and cluing, but me throwing my phone across the room several times at its insane difficulty.
I didn't see who the constructor was until after I finished. I am not surprised it turned out to be Sam Ezersky.

whew, that was a workout!   It took me 250% longer than it takes my usual Sunday time.    

Each and every clue was solvable but you had to look at them from several angles.

Completed and I thought everything looked good, but  107A/108D....that mistaken letter probably took a good 15 minutes to find.

OH WOW, that took me twice as long as Sunday puzzles usually do. It didn't help that the first theme answer I got was PENULTIMATE ANTE, which (reading the title of the puzzle) I took to mean that the trick was taking a phrase like PENNY ANTE and putting a complicated word for start or finish (ULTIMATE) into it. So it kind of worked for that one, but it was no help at all for any of the others. Lots of other little misdirects and errors, but that was the big one.

TIL that PACO is a nickname for Francisco, which was the name of one of my grandfathers. But I can't imagine that he was ever called PACO!
I like a puzzle that adds to my knowledge base or opens me to a wider uses of a word or expression.  This puzzle did neither at any point.  One of the few times I felt I wasted my time.
So challenging and so wonderful!  Extremely chunky and chewy for a Sunday, and such a feeling of a good hard win.

I found this to be a kinder, gentler Sam E. construction. Usually there's a point when I throw my hands up and just hit Reveal. But then again, those might have been Saturday puzzles.   I just kept plugging away, using all the PPE available and finally remembered I should look at the title again and see if I could figure out how the themers worker. Lo and behold, I got it with STANDARDSUB.  
I liked the convertible answer (SPORTY), but I'm giving a little side-eye to ADDY.
Loved it! Yes, 25A and 70A were great. Appreciate 42A, 87A, well, yeah, all of them. Thanks, Sam, for taking a Bee Break for this "21A / 75A."
Heck of a puzzle Sam, thanks for the beefy dinner. The SE corner had me pulling my hair out.
Really enjoyed this one!

Two hours, and I cheated. Definitely on the strugglebus.

AFAIK WAWA does not exist where I am... ditto MSG (how dare the New York Times ask for answers that mostly New Yorkers would know!).

"STANDARDbUn" did not help me at at all. "Footlong" is something I only associate with hot dogs.
I was just wondering who would be mean enough to clue MSG like that, then I noticed the constructor and it all made sense!

Wow did anyone tell Sam this wasn’t a Saturday?
Loved all the theme entries but given the double stack and therefore the preponderance of some more obscure entries, the cluing could have been kinder for a Sunday— I’m looking at you COLMAN/MSG for example. Had to sweat all the way through this. ULTIMATELY I enjoyed it though.

Today’s puzzle was a Sunday delight.  I was very slow to catch the trick of reversing the words in the themed answers, but finally caught on when I got MANAGEDMICRO.  Then I went back admired all the ones I’d gotten without appreciating the cleverness of the construction.

I was happy to see our local convenience chain, WAWA, get a shout out.

My favorite clue was Masters of writing - with its disguised capital and false plural.  EDGARLEE Masters’ Spoon River Anthology is classic Americana, and inspired a fine song of the same name by criminally overlooked singer/songwriter Michael Smith, which I discovered via Steve Goodman’s cover version.

Sorry, but solving the Saturday puzzle late and on the West Coast, I must ask this here:

Why a plural NOSEBLEEDS when the clue is singular ("Stadium section")?

I figured out the theme surprisingly quickly, and I thought ooh, maybe we were getting a break.   But the rest of the too clever clueing made it not a fun solve for me, in the end I gave up. I wish the Times would stop publishing puzzles like this.
Tough one. Is Sam still running the show while Will recovers?
49 minutes until I hit the check puzzle button. Only thing I missed was the AAA/AUK/ASWAN crossing...
Difficult, but lots of fun. I loved “pensive ex.”
I’m actually relieved to see others struggled with this one. Felt like a Saturday in difficulty. Was starting to question my sanity as the clock ticked 16 minutes over my average!
I don't care what the story is about... WHAT KIND OF CLICK BAIT IS THAT HEADLINE???!!!

Ooh that was a tough one.  I look forward to Sundays however this put me back in my place two days after a Friday PB!  Didn't help that I misspelled apocOlyptic which crossed with a name I'd never heard of.  Question: what does "solving dis" mean?  ... never mind just figured it out by writing it out - I always thought it was spelled "diss."

I go through the archives daily and was feeling pretty smug when I got a 4:30 on a Monday “Oldie” from March 2020.  

And I thought to myself: “well, that was a fun race but it’s over so soon.”

Then I opened this Sunday puzzle and it took me three hours working on and off on it. I feel as though I prevailed. 

Good workout. 

HELPS!

I definitely did this one from the STRUGGLEBUS (well, not the themed entries, those I was pretty good with), so I was pretty shocked to find that I had nothing wrong when I finally decided to check puzzle so I could do a lookup without getting a gold star. 

There were a couple areas that were especially difficult for me that I ultimately worked through (at a very high cost of time), but I could not get the crossing of 81A/D with 94A. I mean, I guessed it was likely ASWAN but I hadn't ruled out other starting vowels. Guess I haven't gotten to cities on rivers in my geography game yet. Har! It helps me soooo much out here but not today. 

Too bad I didn't know what a TI-84 was, since battery types show up in the puzzles a lot. It sounded like a plane or something to me. First time I've not made it all on my own on a Sunday in ages!  That A took me down! 

Oh well, it was a grand diversion, for which I'm very appreciative. SOLVINGDIS was definitely my favorite of the themers. I'm sure that will be the case for many of us today. PENSIVEEX is very cute too. 

This made me chuckle after a while: I didn't have a lot (as usual) on a first go through, so at 95A, I was thinking it was maybe a rebus... oooh! A bright spot in a tough week, perhaps!?  Guess I think of Hardy boy(s) much more than I do Hardy HAR, even though I actually use just HAR a fair amount. 

Thanks for a great week of puzzles!!
11D - answers should not start with 'THE'. That is just annoying, because it is completely arbitrary and random when they do. The same would go for 'A' or 'AN'.

Oh, I meant to ask, what does "Thunder shower?" solving to ESPN mean? I got it but didn't get it....

Ohhhhhh, belay that...  I get it now. Shower as in one who shows, not shower as in rain or get clean.  Ack!  I usually catch those faster.  

I reckon the Thunder are a sports team that are shown on ESPN. Noted!

Go, sports!!
Tough, brilliant, over my average, well worth it.
How is “Stirrup’s place” = ear? It doesn’t make any sense

A nit I can't find. Came to the column. No help here. Maddening.  This lovely puzzle, with cool fills like EL GRECO, PENULTIMATE ANTE, EDGAR LEE and Stanley's last name.  All that wonderful stuff I got and gleefully entered, and now this wretched glitch. As Hawkeye said to Cora, in Last of the Mohicans, "I will find you!"  But not tonight. (Yawn)

Thank you, Sam.  I've seen your name so often I've come to think of  you as an old buddy by now.  Great puzzzzzzzzzzzle. Snoring? WAS I?

I look forward to the Sunday puzzle each week:  my favorite.
Speaking only first myself though I rarely enjoy an Ezersky and reading about this one have no plans to finish.  It does not Spark Joy:  Marie Kondo on organizing, decluttering and tidying up the mind.  On to the archive.
Absolutely not on my wavelength.

Saw the Sam Ezersky byline and knew I was in for a challenge. His last puzzle, a Saturday, was borderline impossible. This one was tamer. It was merely improbable. Somewhat more approachable, with a theme that I was slow to catch on to, but I eventually did. Perseverance got me to a 100 day streak.

I needed lookups and autocheck because of an abundance of entries unknown to me, and I actually revealed a few squares, but I found the puzzle quite enjoyable. I got the theme, which doesn't always happen, and I thought it was pretty smart. Most of the clues were on my wavelength, too.

SUB, EX, MICRO, ANTE, PAN, DIS, POST, AUTO, PRO, SUPER

Imagine coming up with ten common prefixes that take on an entirely different meaning when put at the end of a phrase. 

SUPER indeed! 

Great puzzle, Sam.

Well... a record for me. I've never before had less filled in on any puzzle when I finally gave up. Just couldn't get anywhere with this one. 

Couldn't even get many down crosses, so never came close to tumbling to the trick. Actually surprised that most everyone else was able work this one out.

Maybe I can do a Monday. We'll see. 

..

It took me a while to catch on to the theme, but PAN AFRICAN finally cracked it for me.  

I was happy to see Sam's name this morning.  He can be counted on for a fun solve.
Oof. Well averageabove.
least favorite puzzle ever.

Not a horrible puzzle. E-word clues just roll of my back at this point.

But it's a rookie error confusing "Wii Sports" and "Wii Play".

Wii Sports was ubiquitous due to being a pack-in with the Wii console. And was a massive popular and critical success on top of that. It is well remembered to this day.

Wii Play is a terrible collection of glorified tech demos. It is widely hated, and many people only ended up owning it because it came free if you bought a second controller in PAL territories. It is not a "hit" by any definition of the word (except that you hit a billiard ball in one of the minigames).

According to Mobygames' "Mobyscore" metric (based on contemporary critical reviews) , Wii Play is ranked 22136 of ~25.6K Wii games. Which is even worse than it sounds, because some games don't have a score there. Of games with a score, it is in the bottom 150. Easily Putting it in the worst 1% of all games on the system.
Some good ones, couple not so great. “Les Miz” is commonly “Les Mis”. “Crossest” made me cross.
Such a nice puzzle. Such not-nice clues.

What a delightful Word Quirk theme, never done before, best as I can tell. Sam’s notes say that it took months to come up with this theme answer set, and I love hearing about perseverance like that.

Of course, it’s an impressive build, as Sam is a puzzle polisher. Here we have a remarkably dense theme – ten theme answers taking up just shy of a third of the white squares! – smoothly filled, for the most part. Wow! As an elegant touch, he made sure that the only question-mark clues in the across answers were theme answer clues.

It’s also, IMO, a capital-P Puzzle, issuing the challenge: “Crack me!” So many vague clues, clues that could yield several answers, and misdirects. Also, those theme answers weren’t easy to come by. I had a few I’M DYING moments, and overcoming them, as always, was supremely satisfying.

My favorite clue was the misdirect [It’s attached to covers and sheets] for SPINE, which had me retrieving bed instead of book terms. I also liked the fauna references: ROO, PHIL, BABE, a backward BATS, WORM, A$S, and BEES.

Sam, I come into your end-of-the-week puzzles with trepidation and determination, and always leave them with appreciation. This was a beaut, and thank you so much for it!

After this absolutely awful week, I was looking forward to the Sunday crossword, and then to my horror saw the by-line.  NOOOO -- more misery!!!

To my surprise, although it took a bit longer than a typical Sunday, I cracked it, and it did bring me some respite from our sad world.
Who knew that a Saturday clueing will fit into a Sunday grid?

Struggling to come up with additional possible themers--so far I've got is: [Sales pitch for a clergyman](10) And the niche, but very silly [Treebeard's core](6) Just to remind you of possibly the best New Yorker cover ever: https://tinyurl.com/58hb5kad

Delightfully frustrating, always a mere one or two letters beyond reach until the ‘Gotcha!’ moments started ticking in. I’ve never run through the entire alphabet so many times. Time itself flew by, which was just as well, because I needed a lot of it. 
The best kind of Sunday.

I maintain my streak of never once having sussed out a puzzle theme. Many thanks to the editors, without whom I would remain sadly ignorant of the inner beauties of puzzledom.

The emu has a request. It often has its feelings hurt in the comments. So much emudissing! We are founding the International Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Emus and Other Incorporeal Beings, an NGO based in Geneva. (Where else?)
Donations accepted. Emucoin only, please.

Back in the early 1970s when the world was colder and snowier, we had a sledding party, and I ran my Flexible Flyer into a snow-covered stump at the bottom of the hill and received my first concussion. For a week afterward, my thoughts were thick, slow and fuzzy. Reading was almost impossible: the words looked like arranged lines of stones and pebbles, without apparent meaning or connection.

I hope this isn't a political comment that will get bagged by the emus and editors, but after Tuesday, which was a disaster for me and my family, I felt the same way, muddy and dumb. People would talk to me and I'd be unable to comprehend what they said. I refused to read any news, and even worse, I couldn't manage the crossword puzzles. I left yesterday's largely incomplete after three hours' toil. Today's took me 2:25, a minor victory on the road to recovery. I'm wondering if other puzzlers have had a similar experience. 

On to the puzzle itself. Usually I don't light up when I see Sam Ezersky's name. I've been put off by what I saw as braggadocio, lack of humility. This one had none of that, the cluing gentle and funny. I don't think of Poe's works as particularly eerie even when it's about a midnight dreary, but I appreciated having the two most famous literary Edgars sharing space. Some of the themers were a bit strained, but who cares? They worked. 

Glad Sam didn't call it "Transfixed" - that would have incurred a Descent into the Maelstrom from those touchy about those things.
One of the best Sundays ever.  Thanks, Sam.
Sam E's Saturdays can be killer, but the Sundays are just right. Loved the switcheroo theme.  My last placement was the x in PENSIVE EX - my favorite of the themers.  Fun Sunday, thanks to Sam!

Fun, leisurely couple of hours on this one, thanks.
Can anyone please explain "YENTE" for "Broadway gossip"? I've googled it and still no idea. I spent a while down in that part of the puzzle thinking I must have got some wrong crossing words.

FABULOUS puzzle. 
Extra-delightful intro (Joel) and comments (Caitlin). 
Caitlin:  i’m guessing there’s not a solver alive who has not added 70A to their list of all-time favorites.  The answer would be a worthy name for your Complaint Department. 

Special ongoing thanks to Sam Ezersky— as an older annuitant I depend on thezersky puzzles to keep my mind flexible. 

Solving Dis:  “annuitant” is not in Spelling Bee’s Word List. 

Very best regards and wishes.

I’m not saying it was a Sunday puzzle to die for, 

but it did have some cruel suffixion.

Saw the byline
rolled up my sleeves
and was feeling quite chuffed,
flying through the grid
(but in a patchy way)

and my nemesis,
my greatest foe?

The tiny little spot in the east.
Was so sure Liu was Lucy
making I fOld work nicely,
because I a rocket surgeon
who didn’t realize I was apparently
*fine* with
EfGRECO.

Those down answers can look just fine 
when they’re so…not.

But you did not defeat me Sensei Ezersky!

I conquered! 


*CC bows with 🙏 *

IMO, this was just not a good puzzle. Even after giving up and revealing the answers, I still don't understand what the constructor was going for with a lot of these clues. Just absolutely a slog that never paid off.
Wow, this one was hard but fair. A little over double my Sun average.
Well, that was a significant upgrade.
I used to think that the Sunday puzzle was supposed to be the most difficult.  Today it certainly was for me.
Time for an on topic and free read from the paper: https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/10/opinion/crosswords-comfort-crisis.html?unlocked_article_code=1.Y04.G83b.vFbkd2I-14Jb&smid=url-share

Oh silly me, I solved the puzzle in a long time, with lookups of obscure modern persons, but even after reading the column I didn't really dig that prefixes were the core idea.  Thank you to the  commenter who listed them for me, and Ed's, pls note, the recommend button didn't   work on my iPad to reply that way.
Ah. Ok. Got it. Yet another theme where the rearrangement has absolutely no relevance to the puzzle, theme, clueing, reveal. Great. Thanks.
I've never hated a puzzle more than this one full stop

Some puzzles, like this one, are tough but doable with reinforcements -- preferably from skilled solvers of a different generation who happen to be visiting on a weekend. When the circumstances allow, as they did today, those are my favourite puzzles of all.
The clue for ADDY was really poor. Surely there was a better alternative.
Omlet is a word! Today's Letterbox said it's not.

Based on today’s puzzle, here’s  an APOCALYPTICPOST signaling the imminent death of the English language:

“OMG gr8  to EMEET  hit me your ADDY to MIRL” 

Just kidding, of course.

I was so slow in picking up the theme, failing to see it at STANDARD SUB and MANAGED MICRO.  I was also slow to get MICRO, since, as a Government Major, I think I was taught some Economics and that some of it had to do with contrasting "micro" and "macro", but I never really got it straight.  Economics is my second least favorite and least absorbed subject -- right after Geography. 

I didn't yet have PENSIVE EX (which I love!), but I picked up the theme at PENULTIMATE ANTE.  Knowing the theme helped me see APOCALYPTIC POST early.

But the most delightfully clued theme answer of all was SOLVING DIS -- aimed so deliciously right between the eyebrows of all of us solvers.

This gave me everything I want in a Sunday puzzle: humor; cluing that's often playful and can be quite oblique too.  My last answer in was KEN MARE (I had had KENWARE which seemed right to me) after belatedly figuring out that MAIN was the answer to "Not supporting, perhaps" -- which certainly wouldn't come to mind immediately.

A really enjoyable Sunday.  Sam, of course, is a pro.

Big shout out for WAWA! (H/T to Marshall.) The footlong Italian is my STANDARD hoagie (not SUB) but I'll probably go in for a hot turkey Gobbler soon, with stuffing and cranberry sauce.

APOCALYPTIC POST was my favorite themer, and oh-so timely. Not sure about ALT TEXT, though. Usually, when I can't view a photo online, it's because it's NSFW. Oh, and if I'm doing THE WORM at a social event, there's no dancing involved.
I finished the puzzle...was not really on the writer's wave length, so I found it difficult.  And I only saw the theme when I read the blog. .very dense of me, I fear.

Oof! A hard one! But doable. I barely got started last night, then in my first run through this morning couldn't get anything in the Northern section. But it came together.

I think it was hard because the theme didn't "help" much -- even after getting the idea, I had to get a lot of crossing letters to even begin to guess what the theme entries were. And stacking two on top of each other seems a bit unfair!

But again, to those who complained and "gave up" before 9am.... whyyyyyy? There is so much more day left! Don't give up -- put it down and come back to it! There is no greater pleasure than delayed gratification, my friends.
"addy"?? i realy miss Will Shortz.
I finished in record time.  Record slow, that is. Double my Sunday average. Once I figured out how to spell apocalyptic and ran the alphabet on the 69 down 84 across cross, I finished.

I’m getting the West and a few East in the NY Newsday 11/09/24 Saturday stumper! Just much slower. Leaving it around with a pencil. I don’t know what to make of this strike 🪧 but still waiting to come back to the NY Times.

As others have said, some of these seem like they were done hastily. ADDY as an informal term for address? How informal can we get before it’s just nonsense? 

Wonder if Will Shortz would have allowed this one through without more clean up.

My brain likes to compartmentalize, so I often don't fully understand the theme until I've completed the puzzle. But then it takes a quick glance to see what my brain had been pushing aside. 

Today I didn't understand the theme at all. ("Well that not a thing.... neither is that ....") I still didn't get it even after the post-gold star glance. I had to spend a minute looking at the question mark clues to come up with the pattern, and I still don't get all of them. (ANTEPENULTIMATE is a thing?)

So overall, not a satisfying solve, but I don't think that's on the construction but rather is on me. (Though I do think ADDY was indulgent silliness.)
I cannot figure out why ESPN is the answer to the clue "Thunder shower"?. Can someone explain?

It brings up the rear of a truck convoy? 

FINAL SEMI
Germans call it a Biermass, not a stein. I have lifted many to my mouth.

Here to comment that ADDY is commonly used for address, I hear it all the time. Just because it may be out of your lexicon, that doesn't make it a bad clue. 

Anyway, it somehow took me 3:28:18, but the gold star is finally mine. I WIN

After being completely flummoxed by yesterday’s puzzle (especially the SW corner!) today’s was challenging but fun with some clever clues. Picking up on the theme helped me finish up several answers. Good Sunday diversion!

Tough, but fair.

It took me a long time to see the theme.  I had solved six of the themed answers before the penny dropped with PENSIVE EX.  Very clever clue and answer.
After that, things proceeded rather smoothly and quickly.

Ten themed answers!
Very impressive.

And an open question:
Are there too many SOLVING DISses in these comments...or too few?
67D is still a sore spot. Bring back the Sonics!
Not a fan.

No fly-specking, no look-ups, and (just) under 1/2 hour. Nice theme. 
I keep thinking I should honor the strike....but here I am.

Meh.  IMO puzzle would have benefitted from less ambition on the theme density to get cleaner fill overall.  I hadn't looked at the puzzle title and thought a lot of the theme entries were just poorly worded!  Understanding the theme improved my impression of the puzzle, but I think limiting the theme set to ones where the meaning is really shifted and the word-break is in the middle of a word would have been better. So DISSOLVING, EXPENSIVE, and PROVISION are pretty good.  PAN-AFRICAN and SUPERHEATED are relatively lame flips of compound words.  And ANTE-PENULTIMATE feels like a big stretch.  Going for fewer and better theme entries might have made it possible to avoid fill like CROSSEST, YESBABE, and ADDY and not putting ONETON and ONEMONTH in the same puzzle (neither of which are great fill anyway).  Somewhat better solve for me than Sam's last puzzle which I think was a Saturday I really hated.
Wow, that was one kick*** Sunday puzzle. Got it finally but at 33 minutes. I think the longest ever for me for a  Sunday and I've been doing them for about 40 years. Thank you Sam Ezersky.
Some of this was ridiculously obscure. Terrible puzzle. Do better.
This one really needed some editing (there's a English actor named Mark Addy).

Figured it would be a tough one when I saw Ezersky’s name, and it was, but I enjoyed the challenge. Had a giggle at knowing WASI immediately, and I’m in awe of anyone who can do THEWORM! APOCALYPTICPOST seems a bit too on the nose right now, but a great clue. Fun theme.

I always enjoy a Sam Ezersky puzzle, creative and fun. There is always something to learn. The best thing of the day, though, is Natan Last’s op-ed in the NYT. I took Natan’s JASA Crossword Construction class — he was an engaging, kind, and brilliant guy. The NYT is fortunate to have both Sam and Natan. https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/10/opinion/crosswords-comfort-crisis.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare

I want to know why.... when I go to look up a clue to help me with an answer, I simply am unable to go back to the version of the crossword that I was playing/using. I go back to an earlier version that is less filled out than what I have completed to that point. This is beyond frustrating! I get so tired of refilling spaces that should be filled in, that I give up in a Pique! What is going on here, and what can I do to correct this?
Thunder shower=ESPN? Huh?

Could some clarify the clue for 67D [Thunder shower?]

I got it from the crossing but ESPN as the answer still escapes me…

Never got El Greco because I was reading it as “discipline.”

(Try reading the clue.)

I enjoyed Stan crossing Kowalski, even though I am firmly of the belief that it should be Les MiS.

WOW, that was hard work, very few have taken me over the hour.

And while it might allegedly be a thing, if anyone sends me a mail with "Nice to e-meet you", they're on a one-way ticket to the Junk folder

My first themer was PENULTIMATEANTE, but never having heard the term "antepenultimate," the theme remained unclear to me for way too long, which made the rest of the puzzle quite the slog. One of these days, I'll learn to stop working at a puzzle when it starts feeling more like work than play.

It’s really hard for me to enjoy a Sam Ezersky crossword puzzle. Why is that? I find them extremely challenging in a way that doesn’t provide satisfaction to figure out. (Spelling Bees are great)

Second—the blog today! I’d be surprised if folks working on this puzzle didn’t know gravity is less/we WEIGH(T) less on the moon. Or that milky weigh includes NOUGAT.

Maybe EDGARLEE or AUK or some of the other obscure names would have been good to share.
Too many “for short” and “informally” indicating a weak effort to find a decent grid. The theme is in Sam’s head, just not clever enough to mean anything to the solver.
Don't get 'addy' for 122 A

Letting my 346-day streak go in support of the NYT Tech Guild, which is on strike for more fair labor conditions.

Thanks to all the tech workers who make our puzzles so engaging. Sorry the NYT won’t agree to a fair labor contract.

Today when I gave up, again, almost done, as often,, but not quite, I began to wonder if I’ve just aged out of the NYT crossword. Don’t know the current phrases, don’t know actors (even if I’ve seen the movie), I’m learning things, but its not as fun. I was always the party pooper in Trivial Pursuit and I guess I still am. My good categories were science and nature. And luckily I know some French. I love word games. So I guess I’ll hang on for the Bee and Connections and Wordle, but I’m bugging out of here for a bit. 
Peace and good words to you.

Finally finished the NY Newsday Saturday Stumper! Many look-ups but not so ridiculous I ever wondered, “Is this just an online search game?” One answer I didn’t understand though: How are P, C, V or B = ELEM? I get maybe something elementary but don’t exactly know.
Took Friday and Saturday on and off until 5 pm.
How does "Buy-in the round before going all in" = PENULTIMATE ANTE? And what is ANTE PENULTIMATE? Guess I'm missing something...

Solved in slightly shorter than average Sunday time with no cheating, but didn't get the theme until reading this Wordplay. Luckily the puzzle was easy enough to ignore it. Seeing it now, it doesn't add much to the puzzle. Slightly clever, but not in a really satisfying way.
Meh.  I’ve only seen “Les Mis” in print, never MIZ, so that hung me up for a quite a while, as did only knowing the term “ice out” rather than RUN.

Hmm, I started to read the comments and was surprised to see so many negatives.  I thought this was a decent Sunday effort with a reasonable theme.  My only real quibbles were with a lot of the theme choices.  The first two across the top were nice enough, but I thought some of the others were pretty darned "stretchy".

To be completely honest, the only theme answer I thought was any good was the pensive one.  All the others left me cold or seemed obvious or seemed awkward.  Unlike some other recent elaborate themes, I would have guessed this one would have been easier to execute / find samples for.  But I suppose not.

Anyway, still a fun Sunday overall.

/citing answers with grid coordinates is annoying for everyone and I avoid it... If you've made it this far, past the Wordplay column, you've already seen tons of spoilers, it would seem to me...

/Now off to see what my fellow whiners have to say

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

I too found this one took longer than my average... but GUYS!  It's a PUZZLE!!!  It's *supposed* to be a challenge!

I pity the editors... there's no pleasing everyone.  But as a proper addict (though I'm sure my current streak approaching 800 wouldn't impress many in this comments section) I delight in the variety, and the offbeat, and the quirky.  I'm sure there are comforting, easy-to-complete puzzles out there if you just need to check a box every morning.  But I come here to be challenged. Keep it up, New York Times! <3
Not a great puzzle - too forced.  The real head-slapper is "crossest".  Really?
That was fun! I enjoyed it a lot, partly because it was challenging, but not TOO challenging for me. I thought it very clever, too. Thanks, Sam!

None of the tricky clues cited in the column held me up much, but the area around 59, 65, 66, and 67 down, and 70, 75, 79, and 86 across cost me a lot of time and led to a time that was 52% longer that average.  Was trying roam, rove, long before coming up with romp.  Lucy before Simu (whom I've not heard of).  

Not a hard puzzle really, just not in my wheelhouse, especially the aforementioned area.
Terrible. Dogwater puzzle

Clunky and self-indulgent. The inclusion of yet another contrived “e” word answer just cements my opinion of this awkward and unsatisfying grid. I’ve spent more years online than nearly anybody, and at no point did I “emeet” anyone.

Not surprised to see Sam was the author of this puzzle because, although I’m addicted to Spelling Bee, I’ve never been on his wavelength in terms of crosswords.

I found many of the clues to be clunky and forced, and the reveals insufficiently clever. Too many lookups, not enough fun. Not a good Sunday for me.

Western, in London, Ont.

[DIRECTIONALUNI]

Addy?  Really?
Something nobody anywhere ever said.

I got it right, cause no "sprotr," I'm just sayin'...

Sam E.’s puzzles tend to be very overwrought and best described as “too clever by half” and this is no exception. Arbitrarily difficult, not by virtue of fun or whimsical wordplay, but by self-indulgent trivia and glue-y crosswordese fill.

From start to finish, the clunky 3-letter answers were either yawn-inducing (ROO, EAR, MEW) or hair-pulling oblique (MSG, NRC, HAR). The 4-letters weren’t much better: ADDY, SWIT, LINT, PHIL—none of it particularly fun or interesting.

The themed answers were just a very basic form of wordplay where one part of a word gets rearranged and some contrived clue gets used to describe the otherwise nonsensical result. Not particularly fun or interesting, and about as close to themeless as one could reasonably get away with for what’s supposed to be a heavily themed puzzle.

Pile on a truckload of proper names and obscure trivia, and this puzzle (for me at least) failed that most golden of rules: it ultimately does not pass the Sunday morning coffee vibe check.
Hated this one. I don't think I've ever looked at an answer key before. Way, way, way over my average time. I hope we don't get more like this or I'll have to start skipping Sundays.

I was scrolling through the comments in new-to-old order, got about halfway through them before I had had enough.  Too many people venting their anger and hostility over the leisurely pasttime of solving, or attempting to solve, crossword puzzles.  Seems like many are not having fun and I wonder why they continue.
Very amusing puzzle. Nice to have a Sunday crossword with a bit of meat to it.
Ditto to Edward and others. Overly clever and no fun. Solved it with no help, but also no satisfaction. Not a worthy puzzle -- especially for a Sunday.

too obscure for me. 
this one ended my streak.
This was a classic Sam Ezersky puzzle, which reminded me that I don't like Sam Ezersky's puzzles. The theme was okay but I the fill was EH.
Theme clues were so tough until I got the trick.  I am super impressed how many of these clever theme clues were fit into just one puzzle!
It’s been so long since some fun, clever wordplay that I really struggled with this puzzle.

I am never a fan when a puzzle feels laden with proper nouns: UNO, WEST ELM, KENMORE, PHIL, LUANN, WII, MTN DEW, CARTA, MSG, NRC, ASWAN, ARES, LES MIZ, BRANAGH, TINA, SWIT, EDGAR LEE, VESPA, WAWA, EL GRECO, ESPN, SIMU, COLMAN, MARC, CHIRAC, KOWALSKI, BOHRS, and PACO if I noted them all. 

Some were gimmes for me, but it’s my least favorite kind of clue. It tends to feel like trivia you either will know or won’t and can be hard to fill without looking up (in my experience, anyway).

I did enjoy the clever theme when I caught on though!

@Grant - I designed a several online courses over the past 15-20 years. All my courses had to meet ADA requirements and that included, among other things, entering ALT TEXT to all visual elements so that students who have impaired vision could access the same material that sighted students could. 

ALT TEXT is a good thing, even if it added to my workload.

@CaptainQuahog 
Thanks for the explanation.  Forgot I was supposed to look that up.

@CaptainQuahog 
Oh, so it's more editorial jargon. Got it, thanks.

@Grant 

I wouldn't say it's more editorial jargon, like stet and whatnot.

It's part of standards that make the web more accessible to everyone. The alt text can be read aloud so people who can't adequately see the image can understand what's being displayed visually and how it relates to the content of the page.

I believe it also helps with search engine optimization. 

In any case, as CaptainQuahog said it is definitely a good thing.

@Jessica Bloom - The final syllable of a word is called the ultimate or ultima. The syllable before it is called the penultimate = “next to last.” The syllable before that is called the antepenultimate or antepenult = “before the next to last.”

These are used especially when talking about accentuation (stress) in speaking:

When produce is accented on the penultimate syllable, it is the noun for fruits and vegetables; when it is accented on the ultimate, it is the verb for “to make something.”

Directional is accented on the antepenultimate syllable.

I saw it especially after I was restructured out of my job of 20 years a few years back, when friends were trying to help me network with some of their connections. They would write to both, give a little background on each of us, and then encourage connection.

I'm very thankful no one simply disregarded me, or vice versa, for such a trivial thing because building my network in a whole new job search world, after leaving a job which I had found in a printed newspaper want ad, was pretty daunting.  🤷‍♀️

@Charlotte - they are the signs for elements in chemistry (Phosphorus, Carbon, Vanadium, Boron).
@Aslo White Antepenultimate is a longwinded way of saying 'last but two'

@Aslo White

Same here. Never heard the phrase “ante penultimate”. I suppose it means the step before the next to last step which seems like it an expression that would have really limited use.

@Aslo White 

Penultimate means next to last. The penultimate book in a series, for example, comes right before the final book. 

So, the penultimate ante is the ante before someone goes all in on a round of betting.... or the second to last ante. 

In addition to its poker meaning, ante means before, so it would be the third to last book in a series, for example, because it's right before the penultimate book. 

Hope this helps!
Byron, It's not a phrase; it's a word. https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/antepenultimate

Obvious observation of course would be that those finishing earlier are possibly (a) happier with the puzzle because they (b) finished it sooner and/or (c) found it easier and/or (d) are better/smarter solvers and/or (e) are better rested and less cranky.  :)

@B
